questions.text: 1. A female presented with recurrent headaches. Identify the lesion in the given MRI.
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the above patient is meningioma.

Meningioma shows a ‘dural tail’ extending from the tumour along the dura mater.  It is a well-defined, hyperintense and homogeneously enhanced mass that arises from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges. They mostly arise in the supratentorial region, but can also be seen in the infratentorial region.

Meningomas are more commonly seen in females and are associated with the NF-2 mutation. Many small meningiomas are found incidentally and are entirely asymptomatic. Most common presentations include headache, paresis and change in mental status. 

Other options:

Option A: Gliomas are intra-axial tumours.

Option C: Ependymoma arise from the neoplastic transformation of the ependyma. They are usually intraventricular, but extraventricular rests of ependymal cells may give rise to cerebral hemisphere tumours.

Option D: Pilocytic astrocytoma is a benign astrocytoma that typi­cally occurs in children and young adults. MRI reveals a cystic mass.

questions.text: 2. What is the most appropriate statement regarding the given investigation?

choices.text: Invasive and can be therapeutic treatment for bladder calculi
Non invasive and used to diagnose ureteropelvic junction obstruction
Non invasive and gold standard for bladder cancer
Requires percutaneous access to the renal pelvicalyceal system

questions.solution:
The given image shows Intravenous Urography (IVU). It is non-invasive and used to diagnose ureteropelvic junction obstruction.

IVU is a non-invasive radiographic study of the renal parenchyma, pelvicalyceal system, ureters and urinary bladder using intravenous contrast medium.

IVU can help to identify:

* Ureteric obstruction, Ureteropelvic junction obstruction

* Papillary necrosis

* Anatomical variants such as a horseshoe kidney

* The course of the ureters

* Renal function

Intravenous access is required for the injection of a contrast agent. It can be one of two main forms: bolus or drip infusion urography.

questions.text: 3. A 55-year-old male presented with a pulsative swelling in the neck. The swelling was compressible and refilled on removing of pressure. The digital angiography image is given below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with the image showing splaying of internal and external carotid arteries, suggest the diagnosis to be a carotid body tumour, also called a chemodectoma.

Carotid body tumors are mostly benign, neurogenic tumors or paragangliomas arising from the chemoreceptor cells of the carotid bulb. They are related to catecholamine-secreting neuroendocrine tumors like pheochromocytomas and occasionally occur concurrently with them. Familial cases are caused by mutations in the SDH gene. The pathophysiology is believed to be chronic hypoxia in high-altitude states.

Clinical features are a painless, slow-growing, pulsatile lateral neck mass, usually in the 5th decade, firm in consistency moves from side to side but not up to down. The tonsil may be displaced medially. A bruit may be associated with the tumor and sometimes the mass can be emptied and slow refilling occurs.

On the angiogram, splaying of the internal and external carotid arteries at the common carotid bifurcation can be seen. This is known as Lyre's sign, as shown below:



FNAC is absolutely contraindicated. The Shamblin classification is utilised to assess the resectability of these tumors.

Other Options:

Option A: Carotid aneurysm is a swelling in the neck at the level of the thyroid cartilage, below the angle of the mandible. It is pulsatile, smooth, soft, nontender, horizontally mobile, with bruit. Neurological features due to embolic episodes, hoarseness of voice, Horner's syndrome, and dysphagia due to swelling extending into the tonsillar bed may also be present. 

Option C: Strawberry hemangiomas are capillary hemangiomas that may be present at birth or present a few weeks after birth.

Option D: AV fistula is an abnormal communication between an artery and a vein.

questions.text: 4. A newborn is admitted to the NICU after 24hour with severe respiratory distress. What is the diagnosis from the given xray?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect in the diaphragm. Malformation of the diaphragm allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, hindering proper lung formation and resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia, a posterolateral defect which usually involves the left side. 

Other options:

Option A: Congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) is a group of cystic and non-cystic lung lesions resulting from early airway maldevelopment. They can communicate with the airways and are frequently infected.



Option B: Loculated pneumothorax is a form of pneumothorax where a pocket of pleural air is trapped within a localised area.



Option D: Congenital lobar emphysema is a bronchial abnormality that results in a check valve mechanism causing progressive hyperinflation of the affected lobe.



Pearl PM0028: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

* Mediastinal shift

* Bowel loops in the left hemithorax



 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

* Low lung volume

* Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)

* Air bronchogram

* White-out lung (severe disease)



Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

* Hyperinflation

* Patchy infiltrates

* Coarse streaking



Pearl PM2134: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

* The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

* The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

* respiratory distress at birth

* grunting respiration

* chest retractions

* dyspnea

* cyanosis

* scaphoid abdomen

* decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH

* shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: 5. A 50-year-old female has complaints of right flank pain since the past 6 months. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old female with complaints of right flank pain for the past 6 months, and the coronal section of the CT abdomen showing a right renal mass, suggests the lesion to be a right renal neoplasm.  

Renal neoplasm is usually seen in individuals aged 50 to 70 years and usually presents with flank pain, palpable mass in the flank or hematuria. CT is commonly used for the evaluation of a renal mass. On non-contrast CT, lesions are of soft tissue attenuation, while larger lesions frequently have areas of necrosis. Some lesions also have calcification.

The image below shows a normal CT section of the abdomen.
